Critically acclaimed Current Time documentary chronicles families divided by Russiaâs war, disinformation

A new documentary produced by Current Time and directed by journalist and filmmaker Andrey Loshak, âBroken Ties,â has premiered to critical acclaim in Russia. The film shows the human cost for Russians themselves of Putinâs invasion of Ukraine, and ways Kremlin disinformation and state propaganda are tearing Russian families apart.

Filmed over a three-month period, âBroken Tiesâ follows seven Russian families as their relationships deteriorate in the months following the invasion. Among the subjects followed are: Renata, a pediatrician struggling to come to terms with her guilt over Russiaâs involvement in the war, and her mother, Vinera, a fiercely patriotic schoolteacher; and Ekaterina and Artem, a Russian couple so deeply divided on the war that they may divorce. Loshak also interviews Vika, a survivor of Russiaâs bombing of the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, and her brother, Yakov, who dismisses Vikaâs perspective on the war. As ideologies clash, communication becomes strained, and relationships begin to deteriorate. In time, any hope of finding common ground, understanding or reconciliation begins to vanish.

Kenan Aliyev, executive editor at Current Time and executive producer of the film said, âWe are extremely proud of this latest collaboration with Andrey Loshak, and our ability to release this important documentary to Russian-speaking audiences â including in Ukraine â while the war rages on. This documentary shows the real, human costs for Russians themselves of Putinâs assault on media freedom and independent journalism.â

In one of the filmâs most moving scenes, Natalya, a psychologist opposed to Russiaâs invasion, recounts how she regularly talks with her mother Lyudmila for hours, refuting state propaganda. When asked if her daughter has managed to persuade her at all, Lyudmila answers, âNo, of course not.â

âBroken Tiesâ first premiered for Russian-speaking audiences on Current Time on June 20. It is now available onÂ YouTube, where it has been seen over 1.2 million times, generating significant positive audience engagement.

Ksenia Larina, a prominent Russian journalist and television critic, described the film as âastonishingâ and âscary;â and Anton Dolin, a Russian film critic writing for Meduza, called the film, âa powerful antidote to what Russian television has become,â and, âmade by one of the best representatives of a different kind of television…â

Andrey Loshak is an internationally recognized journalist, reporter, and filmmaker from Moscow. He has received the Russian TEFI award for âBest Reporterâ and the Order âFor Merit to the Fatherlandâ 1st class medal for his pioneering work in Russian national TV.
